body.section:
First, read through these:
Design Walkthrough to understand what the tool is trying to do and how
Java API to see the module structure and understand the tool from a client perspective
Pay special attention to the "Developer Guide note" mentions in the Design Walkthrough to see how the design maps to the code.

section.name: Getting started with coding
section.p: Try out any of the unit tests and ITs in the DBMS-specific modules or the scenario test modules.
These will typically invoke deployments against actual DBs and vet that the results in the DB are correct
You can use these to see the full code path executed and trace through as you need to

section.name: Adding a new DBMS implementation
section.h4: 1. Create and setup a blank DB schema to run your tests against
section.p: Obevo will run tests against actual DBMSs that have schemas dedicated to Obevo.
Get a schema to facilitate your testing
You can use obevo-db-db2 or obevo-db-postgresql as examples
section.h4: 3. Implement the classes required to do a basic incremental deployment for simple objects like tables
section.p: These classes revolve around setting up the JDBC parameters and such:
Also implement a DbMetadataDialect for your new implementation in obevo-schemacrawler
Start w/ tables for now; we will get to stored procedures/views/etc. later
section.h4: 4. Implement an integration test in your module
section.p: Most examples will have a "step1" and "step2" - the idea is to do the initial deployment and then a subsequent update so that you can vet both cases
section.h4: 5. Add support for the other DB Object types, e.g. stored procedures, views, static data
6. Add the -cleanFirst command to your test to vet out the cleaning command
section.p: Note that some of the DBMS types require specific sqls to query out the db objects that schemacrawler cannot get to. This would be declared in the *AppContext class if applicable

ol.li: Run the steps in the user guide for reverse-engineering from Aqua
Try the AquaRevengTest for your module to ensure that the code can get formatted into the right structure

Modify the code as needed to get it to work (most of the work is just in parsing the text for the object names, and at this point, hopefully should not require much changes at this point for new DBMS's)
